Chapter 5

Contents

  • Introduction

Chapter 5#

Introduction#

Religious texts, serving as foundational pillars of spiritual and cultural guidance, have shaped societies and personal belief systems for centuries. Yet, each new translation of these texts is not merely an act of linguistic substitution; it brings nuanced shifts that mirror changes in language, culture, and society. This chapter explores how these incremental adjustments in translation can influence readers’ theological understanding, subtly reshaping interpretations of key ideas over time. By tracing these shifts, we aim to uncover the evolving theological perspectives embedded within different English translations, shedding light on how scripture adapts to and reflects its socio-historical context. Religious texts like the Bible are among the most frequently translated works globally, with each version inevitably influenced by the translator’s language, cultural context, and theological outlook. While translation aims to stay true to the original text, it often involves interpretive choices shaped by the translator’s beliefs or the prevailing religious and linguistic norms of the time. This study therefore addresses a key question: How have major English Bible translations, over centuries, reflected and contributed to shifts in theological focus? Through advanced text mining techniques, we systematically examine thematic patterns, keywords, and topics within pivotal English Bible translations spanning over four centuries, including Douay-Rheims (1582, 1601&1610), the King James Version (1611), World English Bible (2000), and Open English Bible (2010). This temporal range allows for the analysis of continuity and change in theological emphasis, tracking shifts that may align with or respond to historical events, doctrinal developments, and societal transformations. To achieve this, we use computational methods in text mining to capture thematic and linguistic changes across these translations. Techniques such as topic modeling, frequency analysis, and keyword comparison enable us to detect subtle yet meaningful changes that may not be immediately apparent in a qualitative review. For instance, we anticipate that terms emphasizing divine authority, morality, or human agency might reveal shifting focal points in theological interpretation. By mapping these changes, this analysis provides empirical evidence of the interplay between scriptural content and the contexts in which these texts were reinterpreted. Through this comparative, computational lens, our study aims to offer a novel perspective on the evolution of religious translation and its impact on theological discourse. This research not only contributes to the fields of computational linguistics and digital humanities but also invites reflection on the broader cultural implications of religious translation, as language remains a living medium through which faith, values, and beliefs are continually reshaped.

## Data

In this chapter, we focus on tracing theological shifts over time by examining four different Bible versions based on criteria such as comparability and accessability, i.e., being open source: the King James Version (KJV), Douay-Rheims Version (DRV), World English Bible (WEB), and Open English Bible (OEB). We chose these translations to give a balanced view of how language and interpretation have evolved, reflecting changes in theological emphasis, linguistic style, and translation philosophy over the centuries. Together, these versions allow us to explore how translation choices can shape the way people understand and connect with biblical texts.

The King James Version (KJV), Douay-Rheims Version (DRV), World English Bible (WEB), and Open English Bible (OEB) each offer a unique approach to translating the Bible, and they highlight how language and interpretation have changed over time. Each translation was created with different goals and priorities, which affect how we read and understand the text. The KJV, published in 1611, is known for its formal, poetic language and is based on manuscripts called the Textus Receptus. It has been very influential in shaping English-speaking Christianity. The DRV, published in 1582 (New Testament) and 1610 (Old Testament) and translated from the Latin Vulgate, is the Catholic counterpart and has a similar formal style (Britannica). On the other hand, the WEB and OEB are modern translations. The WEB updates the language of the American Standard Version, which is based on the KJV, to make it easier to read , while the OEB uses simple, everyday language to make the Bible more accessible to a wider audience . Together, these four translations let us see how biblical language has evolved and how translation choices influence how people connect with the text. One big difference among these versions is how they handle language and readability. The KJV and DRV use older, more complex English, which can be hard for modern readers to understand.

with open("KJV_old_testament.tsv", "r") as f:
    for line in f.readlines():
        a,b,c = line.split("\t")
        print(c)

Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, These are the beast

Whatsoever parteth the hoof, and is clovenfooted, and cheweth th

Nevertheless these shall ye not eat of them that chew the cud, o

And the coney, because he cheweth the cud, but divideth not th

And the hare, because he cheweth the cud, but divideth not th

And the swine, though he divide the hoof, and be clovenfooted

Of their flesh shall ye not eat, and their carcase shall ye no

These shall ye eat of all that are in the waters: whatsoever hat

And all that have not fins and scales in the seas, and in th

Whatsoever hath no fins nor scales in the waters, that shall b

And these are they which ye shall have in abomination among th

All fowls that creep, going upon all four, shall be a

Yet these may ye eat of every flying creeping thing that goet

But all other flying creeping things, which have four feet

And for these ye shall be unclean: whosoever toucheth th

And whosoever beareth ought of the carcase of them shall was

The carcases of every beast which divideth the hoof, and is no

And whatsoever goeth upon his paws, among all manner of beast

And he that beareth the carcase of them shall wash his clothes

These also shall be unclean unto you among the creeping thing

These are unclean to you among all that creep: whosoever dot

And upon whatsoever any of them, when they are dead, doth fall

And every earthen vessel, whereinto any of them falleth

Of all meat which may be eaten, that on which such water comet

And every thing whereupon any part of their carcase fallet

Nevertheless a fountain or pit, wherein there is plenty o

And if any part of their carcase fall upon any sowing seed whic

But if any water be put upon the seed, and any part of thei

And if any beast, of which ye may eat, die; he that toucheth th

And he that eateth of the carcase of it shall wash his clothes

And every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth shall b

Whatsoever goeth upon the belly, and whatsoever goeth upon al

Ye shall not make yourselves abominable with any creeping thin

For I am the LORD your God: ye shall therefore sanctif

For I am the LORD that bringeth you up out of the land of Egypt

This is the law of the beasts, and of the fowl, and of ever

And the LORD spake unto Moses in mount Sinai, saying, 25:2 Spea

Six years thou shalt sow thy field, and six years thou shal

That which groweth of its own accord of thy harvest thou shal

And the sabbath of the land shall be meat for you; for thee, an

And for thy cattle, and for the beast that are in thy land, shal

And thou shalt number seven sabbaths of years unto thee, seve

Then shalt thou cause the trumpet of the jubile to sound on th

And ye shall hallow the fiftieth year, and proclaim libert

A jubile shall that fiftieth year be unto you: ye shall not sow

For it is the jubile; it shall be holy unto you: ye shall ea

In the year of this jubile ye shall return every man unto hi

And if thou sell ought unto thy neighbour, or buyest ought o

Ye shall not therefore oppress one another; but thou shalt fea

Wherefore ye shall do my statutes, and keep my judgments, and d

And the land shall yield her fruit, and ye shall eat your fill

And if ye shall say, What shall we eat the seventh year? behold

And ye shall sow the eighth year, and eat yet of old fruit unti

The land shall not be sold for ever: for the land is mine, fo

And in all the land of your possession ye shall grant 

If thy brother be waxen poor, and hath sold away some of hi

And if the man have none to redeem it, and himself be able t

But if he be not able to restore it to him, then that which i

And if a man sell a dwelling house in a walled city, then he ma

But the field of the suburbs of their cities may not be sold

And if thy brother be waxen poor, and fallen in decay with thee

Thou shalt not give him thy money upon usury, nor lend him th

I am the LORD your God, which brought you forth out of the lan

And if thy brother that dwelleth by thee be waxen poor, and b

But as an hired servant, and as a sojourner, he shall be wit

And then shall he depart from thee, both he and his childre

For they are my servants, which I brought forth out of the lan

Thou shalt not rule over him with rigour; but shalt fear th

For unto me the children of Israel are servants; they are m

And the afflicted people thou wilt save: but thine eyes are upo

There was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was Job; and tha

And there were born unto him seven sons and three daughters

His substance also was seven thousand sheep, and three thousan

And his sons went and feasted in their houses, every one his day

And it was so, when the days of their feasting were gone about

After this opened Job his mouth, and cursed his day

And Job spake, and said, 3:3 Let the day perish wherein I wa

Let that day be darkness; let not God regard it from above

Let darkness and the shadow of death stain it; let a cloud dwel

As for that night, let darkness seize upon it; let it not b

Lo, let that night be solitary, let no joyful voice come therein

Let them curse it that curse the day, who are ready to raise u

Let the stars of the twilight thereof be dark; let it look fo

Why died I not from the womb? why did I not give up the ghos

With kings and counsellors of the earth, which build desolat

There the wicked cease from troubling; and there the weary be a

There the prisoners rest together; they hear not the voice of th

The small and great are there; and the servant is free from hi

Wherefore is light given to him that is in misery, and life unt

For my sighing cometh before I eat, and my roarings are poure

For the thing which I greatly feared is come upon me, and tha

I was not in safety, neither had I rest, neither was I quiet; ye

The old lion perisheth for lack of prey, and the stout lion’

Now a thing was secretly brought to me, and mine ear received

When the ear heard me, then it blessed me; and when the eye sa

The blessing of him that was ready to perish came upon me: and 

I put on righteousness, and it clothed me: my judgment was as 

I was eyes to the blind, and feet was I to the lame

I was a father to the poor: and the cause which I knew not 

And I brake the jaws of the wicked, and plucked the spoil out o

Then I said, I shall die in my nest, and I shall multiply m

My root was spread out by the waters, and the dew lay all nigh

My glory was fresh in me, and my bow was renewed in my hand

After my words they spake not again; and my speech dropped upo

And they waited for me as for the rain; and they opened thei

And now my soul is poured out upon me; the days of afflictio

My bones are pierced in me in the night season: and my sinew

He hath cast me into the mire, and I am become like dust an

Did not I weep for him that was in trouble? was not my sou

My bowels boiled, and rested not: the days of afflictio

I went mourning without the sun: I stood up, and I cried in th

I am a brother to dragons, and a companion to owls

I made a covenant with mine eyes; why then should I think upon

The proverbs of Solomon the son of David, king of Israel; 1:2 T

To receive the instruction of wisdom, justice, and judgment, an

A wise man will hear, and will increase learning; and a man o

The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge: but fool

My son, hear the instruction of thy father, and forsake not th

My son, if sinners entice thee, consent thou not

If they say, Come with us, let us lay wait for blood, let us lur

We shall find all precious substance, we shall fill our house

My son, walk not thou in the way with them; refrain thy foot fro

Surely in vain the net is spread in the sight of any bird

And they lay wait for their own blood; they lurk privily fo

So are the ways of every one that is greedy of gain; which taket

Wisdom crieth without; she uttereth her voice in the streets

She crieth in the chief place of concourse, in the openings o

Because I have called, and ye refused; I have stretched out m

Then shall they call upon me, but I will not answer; they shal

Therefore shall they eat of the fruit of their own way, and b

For the turning away of the simple shall slay them, and th

But whoso hearkeneth unto me shall dwell safely, and shall b

My son, if thou wilt receive my words, and hide my commandment

For the LORD giveth wisdom: out of his mouth cometh knowledge an

He layeth up sound wisdom for the righteous: he is a buckler t

He keepeth the paths of judgment, and preserveth the way of hi

Then shalt thou understand righteousness, and judgment, an

When wisdom entereth into thine heart, and knowledge is pleasan

For her house inclineth unto death, and her paths unto the dead

None that go unto her return again, neither take they hold of th

That thou mayest walk in the way of good men, and keep the path

For the upright shall dwell in the land, and the perfect shal

But the wicked shall be cut off from the earth, and th

My son, forget not my law; but let thine heart keep m

Let not mercy and truth forsake thee: bind them about thy neck

Trust in the LORD with all thine heart; and lean not unto thin

In all thy ways acknowledge him, and he shall direct thy paths

Be not wise in thine own eyes: fear the LORD, and depart fro

It shall be health to thy navel, and marrow to thy bones

Honour the LORD with thy substance, and with the firstfruits o

My son, despise not the chastening of the LORD; neither be wear

Happy is the man that findeth wisdom, and the man that gettet

For the merchandise of it is better than the merchandise o

She is more precious than rubies: and all the things thou cans

Length of days is in her right hand; and in her left hand riche

Her ways are ways of pleasantness, and all her paths are peace

She is a tree of life to them that lay hold upon her: and happ

The LORD by wisdom hath founded the earth; by understanding hat

By his knowledge the depths are broken up, and the clouds dro

My son, let not them depart from thine eyes: keep sound wisdo

Then shalt thou walk in thy way safely, and thy foot shall no

When thou liest down, thou shalt not be afraid: yea, thou shal

Be not afraid of sudden fear, neither of the desolation of th

For the LORD shall be thy confidence, and shall keep thy foo

Withhold not good from them to whom it is due, when it is in th

Say not unto thy neighbour, Go, and come again, and to morrow 

Devise not evil against thy neighbour, seeing he dwellet

Strive not with a man without cause, if he have done thee n

Envy thou not the oppressor, and choose none of his ways

For the froward is abomination to the LORD: but his secret i

The curse of the LORD is in the house of the wicked: but h

Surely he scorneth the scorners: but he giveth grace unto th

The wise shall inherit glory: but shame shall be the promotion o

Hear, ye children, the instruction of a father, and attend to kno

For I give you good doctrine, forsake ye not my law

For I was my father’s son, tender and only beloved in the sight o

He taught me also, and said unto me, Let thine heart retain m

Get wisdom, get understanding: forget it not; neither decline fro

Forsake her not, and she shall preserve thee: love her, and sh

Wisdom is the principal thing; therefore get wisdom: and with al

Exalt her, and she shall promote thee: she shall bring thee t

She shall give to thine head an ornament of grace: a crown o

Hear, O my son, and receive my sayings; and the years of thy lif

I have taught thee in the way of wisdom; I have led thee in righ

When thou goest, thy steps shall not be straitened; and when tho

Take fast hold of instruction; let her not go: keep her; for sh

Enter not into the path of the wicked, and go not in the way o

Avoid it, pass not by it, turn from it, and pass away

For they sleep not, except they have done mischief; and thei

For they eat the bread of wickedness, and drink the wine o

But the path of the just is as the shining light, that shinet

The way of the wicked is as darkness: they know not at what the

My son, attend to my words; incline thine ear unto my sayings

Let them not depart from thine eyes; keep them in the midst o

For they are life unto those that find them, and health to al

Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it are the issue

Put away from thee a froward mouth, and perverse lips put fa

Let thine eyes look right on, and let thine eyelids look straigh

Ponder the path of thy feet, and let all thy ways be established

Turn not to the right hand nor to the left: remove thy foot fro

My son, attend unto my wisdom, and bow thine ear to m

For the lips of a strange woman drop as an honeycomb, and he

Her feet go down to death; her steps take hold on hell

Hear me now therefore, O ye children, and depart not from th

Remove thy way far from her, and come not nigh the door of he

A naughty person, a wicked man, walketh with a froward mouth

For the commandment is a lamp; and the law is light; and reproof

For by means of a whorish woman a man is brought to a piece o

Can a man take fire in his bosom, and his clothes not be burned

But whoso committeth adultery with a woman lacketh understanding

For jealousy is the rage of a man: therefore he will not spare i

He will not regard any ransom; neither will he rest content

For at the window of my house I looked through my casement, 7:

(She is loud and stubborn; her feet abide not in her house: 7:1

Therefore came I forth to meet thee, diligently to seek thy face

I have decked my bed with coverings of tapestry, with carve

I have perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon

Come, let us take our fill of love until the morning: let u

For the goodman is not at home, he is gone a long journey: 7:2

With her much fair speech she caused him to yield, with th

He goeth after her straightway, as an ox goeth to the slaughter

Hearken unto me now therefore, O ye children, and attend to th

Let not thine heart decline to her ways, go not astray in he

For she hath cast down many wounded: yea, many strong men hav

Her house is the way to hell, going down to the chambers o

Doth not wisdom cry? and understanding put forth her voice? 8:

Unto you, O men, I call; and my voice is to the sons of man

Hear; for I will speak of excellent things; and the opening of m

For my mouth shall speak truth; and wickedness is an abominatio

All the words of my mouth are in righteousness; there is nothin

They are all plain to him that understandeth, and right to the

Receive my instruction, and not silver; and knowledge rather tha

For wisdom is better than rubies; and all the things that may b

I wisdom dwell with prudence, and find out knowledge of witt

The fear of the LORD is to hate evil: pride, and arrogancy, an

Counsel is mine, and sound wisdom: I am understanding; I hav

By me kings reign, and princes decree justice

By me princes rule, and nobles, even all the judges of the earth

I love them that love me; and those that seek me early shall fin

Riches and honour are with me; yea, durable riches an

My fruit is better than gold, yea, than fine gold; and my revenu

I lead in the way of righteousness, in the midst of the paths o

The LORD possessed me in the beginning of his way, before hi

I was set up from everlasting, from the beginning, or ever th

When there were no depths, I was brought forth; when there wer

Before the mountains were settled, before the hills was I brough

When he prepared the heavens, I was there: when he set a compas

Now therefore hearken unto me, O ye children: for blessed ar

Hear instruction, and be wise, and refuse it not

Blessed is the man that heareth me, watching daily at my gates

For whoso findeth me findeth life, and shall obtain favour of th

But he that sinneth against me wrongeth his own soul: all the

Wisdom hath builded her house, she hath hewn out her seve

She hath sent forth her maidens: she crieth upon the highes

Forsake the foolish, and live; and go in the way of understanding

He that reproveth a scorner getteth to himself shame: and he tha

Reprove not a scorner, lest he hate thee: rebuke a wise man, an

Give instruction to a wise man, and he will be yet wiser: teach

For by me thy days shall be multiplied, and the years of thy lif

The proverbs of Solomon. A wise son maketh a glad father: but 

Treasures of wickedness profit nothing: but righteousnes

The LORD will not suffer the soul of the righteous to famish: bu

He becometh poor that dealeth with a slack hand: but the hand o

He that gathereth in summer is a wise son: but he that sleepet

Blessings are upon the head of the just: but violence coveret

The memory of the just is blessed: but the name of the wicke

The wise in heart will receive commandments: but a prating foo

He that walketh uprightly walketh surely: but he that pervertet

He that winketh with the eye causeth sorrow: but a prating foo

The mouth of a righteous man is a well of life: but violenc

Hatred stirreth up strifes: but love covereth all sins

In the lips of him that hath understanding wisdom is found: bu

Wise men lay up knowledge: but the mouth of the foolish is nea

The rich man’s wealth is his strong city: the destruction of th

The labour of the righteous tendeth to life: the fruit of th

He is in the way of life that keepeth instruction: but he tha

He that hideth hatred with lying lips, and he that uttereth 

In the multitude of words there wanteth not sin: but he tha

The tongue of the just is as choice silver: the heart of th

The lips of the righteous feed many: but fools die for want o

The king answered and said to Daniel, whose name wa

But as for me, this secret is not revealed to me for any wisdo

Thou, O king, sawest, and behold a great image. This great image

Thou sawest till that a stone was cut out without hands, whic

Then was the iron, the clay, the brass, the silver, and the gold

This is the dream; and we will tell the interpretation thereo

Thou, O king, art a king of kings: for the God of heaven hat

And wheresoever the children of men dwell, the beasts of th

And after thee shall arise another kingdom inferior to thee, an

The word of the LORD that came to Joel the son of Pethuel

He hath laid my vine waste, and barked my fig tree: he hath mad

Is not the meat cut off before our eyes, yea, joy and gladnes

The WEB keeps the same basic structure as the KJV but modernizes the language to make it clearer. Meanwhile, the OEB focuses on being as readable as possible, using simple and straightforward language. To illustrate this, in Psalm 23:1, the KJV says, “The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want,” which uses an older way of saying that God provides everything we need. The OEB translates this as, “The Lord is my shepherd; I have all that I need,” which is much clearer for today’s readers. These differences show how translations can make the text more or less accessible, depending on the language they use (citation??). Theological emphasis is another important area where these translations differ. The DRV was translated from the Latin Vulgate and reflects Catholic beliefs , while the KJV comes from the Protestant tradition and has its own way of highlighting certain theological ideas . The WEB and OEB, being more modern and neutral, try to appeal to a broader audience. They avoid some of the theological specifics you find in the older translations. For instance, in Matthew 6:11, the DRV says, “Give us this day our supersubstantial bread,” which ties into Catholic teachings about the Eucharist. The KJV uses the simpler phrase “daily bread,” and the OEB goes even further, translating it as “the food we need for today,” which focuses on the practical meaning rather than theological implications. These differences show how translation choices can subtly influence how readers interpret theological concepts. The sources used for these translations also affect how they read. The KJV is based on the Textus Receptus, which was the best manuscript source available during the Reformation (Britannica), while the DRV comes from the Latin Vulgate, the official Bible of the Catholic Church . The WEB and OEB, however, use more recent and diverse manuscript sources. This can lead to differences in how certain passages are presented. A good example is 1 John 5:7–8. The KJV includes a Trinitarian phrase that’s missing from most early Greek manuscripts but is present in the Textus Receptus. The OEB and WEB, which use critical editions of the Bible based on older manuscripts, leave this phrase out. These differences highlight how the manuscripts chosen for a translation can influence the final text, especially in areas with theological significance. Finally, the translation philosophy behind each version affects how they communicate the original message. The KJV, DRV, and WEB all use a formal, word-for-word approach, which tries to stay as close to the original language as possible. This method often preserves the structure and vocabulary of the original texts but can be harder to read today. The OEB, on the other hand, uses a more dynamic approach, translating the meaning of each passage into natural, modern English. This makes the text easier to understand but can sometimes lose the feel of the original. In Philippians 4:13, for example, the KJV says, “I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me,” which is quite close to the original Greek wording. The OEB simplifies this to, “I can find strength for anything through him who gives me strength,” which is more relatable for modern readers. These different approaches show how translations can either stick closely to the original or make the text easier to read, and each choice affects how people connect with the Bible. In summary, the KJV, DRV, WEB, and OEB give us a wide view of how Bible translation has changed over time. The older translations like the KJV and DRV emphasize tradition and formal language, while the WEB and OEB aim to make the text clearer and more understandable for today’s readers. Comparing these versions reveals how language, theology, and translation methods all work together to shape how we experience and interpret the Bible.

By Phillip B. Ströbel
